awd_titl_txt: Multi-Information Source Value of Information Based Design of Multiphase Structural Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research project is to create a multi-information source value-of-information based framework for the design of complex, multi-component, multi-phase advanced steels. In materials science a material design problem that exploits the chemistry-processing-microstructure-properties paradigm is often expensive, time consuming and limited by the available resources. Thus, to achieve a design goal, one must carefully select the information source to query, which could be an experiment, a computational simulation, elicitation of expert opinion, etc., based on the value added to the design problem, as well as the time/cost associated with performing the query. The complex microstructures in advanced steels result in significant improvements in strength and ductility compared to conventional steels. This makes such steels especially attractive for automotive applications, where vehicle weight reduction and crashworthiness are paramount. The approach is a completely new and potentially transformative way of looking at materials design in general. Here, experiments, simulations, and prior knowledge are accounted for at the same level, potentially alleviating major drawbacks of established paradigms in that there is no longer any required alignment between inputs and outputs of computational or experimental methods. The information source fidelity is implicitly accounted for, and the design framework can efficiently allocate limited resources to the materials design task in an information-economic sense. The research will also be integrated with the NSF Research and Traineeship Program at Texas A&M and outreach to broader communities through existing programs at Texas A&M.

The objective of this research is to exploit the chemistry-processing-microstructure-properties paradigm in materials design within a framework that facilitates the integration of multiple information sources. It prescribes optimal information acquisition protocols that balance exploration and exploitation of the design space. This framework will extend state-of-the-art knowledge gradient policies for value of information based optimal querying of information sources. Key contributions of the framework include enabling parallel querying of correlated information sources by fitting Gaussian process models to learned correlations; incorporation of information sources with differing input/output spaces by leveraging high dimensional model representations; and multi-objective policies that provide scalar indicators of expected improvement through novel importance reweighting of prior queried information into state-of-the-art hypervolume indicators. Contrary to many existing materials design frameworks, the framework directly connects materials chemistry/processing to property, avoiding issues related to discrepancies between optimality and feasibility. The framework will be able to accommodate predictions of mechanical properties with models of different resolution and, more importantly, allows for the integration of experiments and prior knowledge within the same unified framework. Although the demonstration focus is on low alloy multi-phase advanced steels, the methodology is potentially applicable to a wide range of materials systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The most significant intellectual merit of this project was the creation of a materials design framework firmly rooted in rigorous engineering design practice. The framework is based on the value of information where multiple information sources connecting different aspects of the chemistry/processing-microstructure-properties paradigm are queried based on their value added to a design outcome, the cost of performing the query, as well as the value of the queried source relative to learning about the entire system.  The use of the novel value-gradient querying policy, which builds off the knowledge gradient policy, enabled the ability to allocate resources sequentially across a variety of information sources of varying fidelity and cost.  The incorporation of batch Bayesian optimization techniques in open source code developed in this project, BAREFOOT, enabled parallel querying options across all available information sources.  The project also saw the creation of multi-objective querying strategies with both resource constraints and engineering constraints through the use of a multi-information source hypervolume indicator strategy.   Contrary to many existing frameworks for materials design, this project explicitly accounted for chemistry/processing-structure-property relationships, avoiding issues related to discrepancies between optimality and feasibility of materials design solutions. The framework also accommodates predictions of mechanical properties with models of different resolution and, more importantly, allows for the integration of experiments and prior knowledge within the same unified framework.   The bringing together of many different information sources across a modeling chain naturally brings about computational overhead due to the cost of information acquisition.  The project also saw the creation of novel multi-information source active subspace based approaches for dimension reduction, enabling far more efficient and scalable search than was possible previously.

 Demonstration of the framework included many test problems as well as a dual phase steel application problem that included the entire chemistry/processing-structure-properties chain.  Although this problem was the primary focus, the framework is applicable to a wide range of materials systems as the value of information metric is agnostic with regards to the material system, as well as the nature of the sources used to connect design choices to design outcomes.

 From the perspective of broader impacts, education in materials science and design was enhanced at Texas A&M University.  Through involvement with the Texas A&M NSF NRT program at the intersection of materials science, informatics, and design, the graduate students in the project team were able to integrate ideas from informatics and design with the objective of accelerating the development of materials.  Specifically, the project contributed significantly to the development of a new interdisciplinary course at Texas A&M termed the “Materials Design Studio”, which supported the education of a diverse cohort of students in the areas of materials design and informatics.   Members of the project team also actively participated in the IIMEC School in Computational Materials Science. The school was supported by the NSF through the International Institute for Multifunctional Materials for Energy Conversion (IIMEC) and research from this project was used to develop case studies for the school.

 


Last Modified: 09/15/2021
Modified by: Douglas L Allaire
